title: Trump Eager To Pass Immigration Reform, Is Willing To Compromise
text:
Trump Eager To Pass Immigration Reform, Is Willing To Compromise "It could be good for everyone." by Andrew Kerr February 28, 2017 at 5:04pm Advertisement - story continues below 
President Donald Trump’s famed deal-making skills may soon be put to the test. 
Senior administration officials said Tuesday the president is envisioning a major compromise on immigration legislation that would allow allow some illegal immigrants to stay in the United States without risk of deportation. 
Trump believes the country is ready to have the conversation, but understands both sides of the political aisle would need to come together in order to pass immigration reform. Advertisement - story continues below Trump Signs Executive Order To Revise ‘Horrible’ Rule, Rein In EPA 
It would require “a softening on both sides. There’s got to be a coming together,” a senior administration official said. 
On his part, the official said Trump is envisioning a proposal to allow non-violent illegal immigrants to stay and work in the country with one stipulation: there would be no pathway to citizenship. 
Such a proposal would stop short of the measure proposed in the failed Gang of Eight bill from 2013, which would have created a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. Advertisement - story continues below 
According to the official, the president’s envisioned compromise bill might also include an exception for “Dreamers”— illegal immigrants brought to the United States as children. 
It’s unclear whether Trump’s immigration compromise would constitute a reversal from his hard-line campaign promises. 
On the campaign trail, Trump made very clear that he would enforce the current immigration laws to “get the bad ones out.” 
Since assuming office, Trump has already put in place policies to fulfill that promise. In February, he directed the federal government to more aggressively arrest and deport “criminal aliens” who disregard the “rule of law and pose a threat” to American citizens. Advertisement - story continues below 
Also in February, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly authorized the hiring of 10,000 additional immigration officers to more “effectively enforce the immigration laws.” 
In regards to non-violent illegal immigrants, Trump opted for a more mild approach during the campaign. 
When Trump was asked if he would deport non-violent illegal immigrants in August, he responded, “It’s a very, very hard thing … to take a person who’s been here for 15 or 20 years and throw them and their family out.” 
During the campaign, the president indicated that citizenship would be off the table for non-violent illegal immigrants, but left the door open to working with such individuals if they were to pay back-taxes. Trump, in excerpt of townhall with Hannity, on what to do with undocumented immigrants. Whooo boy: pic.twitter.com/VT5mE1EXpZ 
— Phil Mattingly (@Phil_Mattingly) August 24, 2016 
Since both sides would need to compromise, Trump believes it’s possible to fashion an immigration reform bill that would please both the “far right” and “far left.” 
“It has to be a negotiation,” the administration official said. “It could be good for everyone.” 
The president will discuss the enforcement of current immigration laws during his speech tonight to a joint session of congress, and is considering adding the topic of immigration reform as well. What do you think? Scroll down to comment below. Advertisement Popular Right Now
